results.title: Marjorie Barnard
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Historical novelist, Marjorie Barnard recalls priceless memories of fellow writers who “peopled her world”, including Xavier Herbert, Vance and Nettie Palmer and Frank Dalby Davison.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: Gwen Harwood
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A charming film of poet Gwen Harwood speaking at her home in Tasmania about her work in poetry and her love for music and opera.

results.title: A.D. Hope
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A D Hope talks in this entertaining interview of his childhood and its influence on his poetry, and the conflict with his life as a critic and academic.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: Douglas Stewart
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Playwright and poet, Douglas Stewart, was for many years the Literary Editor of the Bulletin, and friend of many writers and artists, including Norman Lindsay, Judith Wright and David Campbell.

results.title: Alan Marshall
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A memorable discussion with an author of extraordinary spirit and charm, who is internationally known for his novel “I Can Jump Puddles”.

results.title: No more secrets
results.brief_description: Explores the issues of Child Abuse and provides strategies for both children and adults to enable them to deal with “secrets” which children often feel obliged to keep to themselves.

results.title: Heaven help us!
results.creator_credit: Robert Kingsbury, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: There’s only one thing wrong with telephones: people use them. This film sets out to explain the simple rules of telephone etiquette with special effects and fantasy sequences. Max Meldrum plays an angel, who for some reason is in charge of heaven’s communications systems! Using a shonky business as an example, he explains the do’s and dont’s of good communication over the phone. Produced for the Australian Post Office.

results.title: An Australian Summer
results.brief_description: A gentle comedy exploring, on a humorous and compassionate level, the shifting relationships within an Australian family over two decades, 1960-1980. The complexities of a family relationship where love as a binding force is tested by disappointment, are evocatively portrayed with a deft mixture of humour and poignancy.

results.title: No myth
results.creator_credit: Claire Jager and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: This video exposes the entrenched attitudes and myths surrounding Australia’s most hidden crime: domestic violence. “No Myth” was produced to explain why secrecy, shame and misplaced guilt accompanies domestic violence, and why women who experience it are frequently too scared, ashamed and isolated to confide in anyone.

results.title: Louder than words
results.brief_description: A documentary about contemporary performance poetry featuring the work of Melbourne poets Ania Walwicz, Eric Beach and Jas H. Duke. They perform in their own exuberant, idiosyncratic and sometimes bizarre way a selection of their own works.
